thread.title_full: Whatatheft: Denton County police want people to stop stealing Whataburger order numbers | Crime | Dallas News

author: dallasnews
title: Whatatheft: Denton County police want people to stop stealing Whataburger order numbers | Crime
text:
A Denton County police department wants Whataburger customers to stop stealing the restaurant's orange plastic order numbers.
The Northeast Police Department, which serves Cross Roads and Krugerville, said in a Facebook post Saturday that is has been made aware that it is a "game" for area teens to take the numbers.
"The issue has become very apparent when we (NEPD), at times possess more of these numbers than the restaurant does," the department said.
In one photo, the department shows a side by side comparison of the numbers they recovered in one incident compared with stack still remaining in a Whataburger.
Stack of Whataburger numbers recovered by police, left, and those remaining in the restaurant. (Northeast Police Department) Whataburger numbers recovered by Northeast police in one incident. (Northeast Police Department) Those numbers — 70 of them — were recovered during an unrelated traffic stop about two weeks ago, Northeast Police Chief James Edland told the Fort Worth Star-Telegram .
"Whataburger is ordering a new bundle (of the numbers) every week because they disappear so fast," he said. "It might be a cool thing to do, but it's still stealing."
Commenters on the department's Facebook post wondered if there wasn't other crimes police could be cracking down on instead, though some noted the importance of teaching teens to respect personal property.
Another commenter asked whether police had any 93's in the stack so they could complete their collection.
Whataburger doesn't seem to be fazed — at least on Twitter — by the vanishing table tents, something that has undoubtedly been happening for years.
@meganmoneyyyy Now that's a huge collection lol!
— Whataburger® (@Whataburger) February 27, 2017 Those caught with the stolen numbers face a citation for theft of property under $100, police said.
